title: 104_hr1972
content: The "Independent Contractor Tax Simplification Act of 1995" aims to simplify tax rules for independent contractors based on recommendations from the 1995 White House Conference on Small Business. Congress recognizes the need for fair and objective guidelines to distinguish between employees and independent contractors. SEC. 3511 introduces standards for determining whether individuals are not employees under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3511 introduces standards for determining if individuals are not employees under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If specific requirements are met, the service provider, recipient, and payor will not be treated as employees for the service provided. The requirements include significant investment in assets or training, incurring unreimbursed expenses, and agreeing to perform the service for a set amount. The service provider must agree to perform a service for a specific time or result, be paid on a commission basis, or purchase products for resale. Additional requirements include having a principal place of business, not primarily working at the recipient's place of business, or paying fair market rent. The service provider is not required to work exclusively for the recipient. In the year involved, or in the preceding or subsequent year, the service provider must have performed a significant amount of service for other persons or offered to do so through various means. The individual providing services must operate under a registered business name and have a written contract stating they are not an employee for tax purposes. If a service recipient or payor fails to meet reporting requirements for a service provider, the provider may not be treated as an employee unless there is reasonable cause. If the service provider operates through an entity they own, the entity may be included in the references, and the written contract can be with either the provider or the entity. Definitions for terms related to service providers are provided in this section. A service provider is defined as an individual who performs services for another person. The service recipient is the person for whom the service provider performs the service, and the payor is the person who pays the service provider if the service recipients do not. The term "in connection with performing the service" refers to activities related to the actual service provided. The section provides definitions for service providers, service recipients, and payors. It states that a service provider performs services for a service recipient or for their trade or business. Exceptions include entities owned by the service provider. The amendments made by this Act regarding standards for determining employee status shall apply to services performed after December 31, 1995.
